numbered_ace_sentences: 1. The graph shows some dots.
2. Young adults are often more hopeful about the future than people who are over 40 years old.
3. The hopefulness is not extremely dependent on the geographical location of a country.
4. The dots are mixed.
5. The dots have a wide range.
6. I am curious about what the people thought about when they answered the questions.
7. I wonder what the people thought defines the world getting better.
8. I wonder whether the people thought about their own individual lives.
9. I also wonder whether the people thought about the world as a whole.
10. The graph provides information about individuals across the world.
11. The graph provides information about the views of these individuals about how the world is changing.
12. The graph can make it clearer how young adults view the world.
13. The graph can make it clearer how older adults view the world.
14. The graph can suggest why the world is changing in some ways.
15. I can learn about my community from the graph.
16. I can learn how my community may want to change the world.
17. I can learn how my community may want to keep the world the same.
18. The graph can suggest how my community wants to change the world.
19. The graph can suggest how many other communities want to change the world.
20. The graph can suggest that young adults may make choices that differ from the choices of older adults.
21. The headline is: Youth waiting to change the world.
